content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												One of my all time favourites. Great strategy game. The campaign is nice, but the skirmish matches are the best. The bots AI is a bit too op on Expert mode (they always know where you are). There were multiple games where I had to "migrate" my settlers to my friends base, or just spent the whole game hiding from the bots (which, again, always find us). Here's a small list of weird funny matches I played on, mainly when I was just starting out and was a noob: - Against a french player, he made a square with his horses and placed one horse of a different type in the middle of the square. The square was incredible fast and basically destroyed all my buildings in under a minute- There was this one guy who made like 50 cannons (no other units) and they would simply destroy everything that I threw at them. After destroying my buildings he spent 10 minutes chasing my last settlers with his army of cannons.- On this one game after I was defeated my friend hid his explorer on a treasure, in a way that it wouldn't be visible from above. After getting to imperial and researching spies to see the whole map, they spent 15 min looking for him until his explorer attacked a settler passing nearby.It's a shame ESO online is terrible. The system is so old I can't even join a single game. This game would become so much better if there was a steam based multiplayer mode. As it is, I have to use gameranger to be able to play with my friends.Also worth mentioning, if you lose your password for ESO Online good luck retrieving it. I had an old copy of the game but couldn't remember the password, emailed microsoft, asked on the official forums and never got an answer. I then bought the game on steam only to find that I couldn't join online games...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This was the first strategy game that I had ever played and having tried many, many others, this is always a treat to come back to. I first had it on a disc for mac but that computer broke years ago. I got a laptop quite recently and saw that there was a complete collection of the game. On sale, I couldn't resist coming back to it and it was worth it. The base game was good with easy, simple mechanics and a fair bit of content, without much range between countries (with the exception of the Ottomans and Russians). The expansions however, add a huge range of content, with vastly different playing styles for different countries and it's still very balanced.My favourite map remains Caribean but all of the new ones I have tried are very good too. I haven't gotten on to the new campaigns yet. The first campaigns weren't particularly compelling in story but the play modes are unique compared to the 'skirmish mode' so it's worth a play-through.This is an absolute classic of real time strategy games and it is deserved of any praise it gets.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
Age of Empires III is a great base-building RTS game for older and less powerful rigs.This game will run on almost any machine that will run Windows 10 as long as it has the space requirements met.  It's quick to load and easy to host/join.  It's not online-only.  It has single-player campaigns, one for the base game and one for each expansion, and it has LAN support.  (It has online features, too, though I never mess with that.)The game is real-time strategy or RTS at its core.  It offers a lot of resource-gathering options and many ways to creatively gain a foothold over your competition.  It also has hilarious cheats! If you don't care to cheat your way to victory but need an edge over everyone else on the battlefield, there is the handicap percentage.Why do I play this so often over all my other RTS games?My wife's laptop can't play much else.  That's the biggest reason.  We like playing strategy games cooperatively and AOE3 is one of the best-looking, most fun experiences we've got to work on her laptop.  Someday, I want to build her a gaming desktop out of my old parts so she can play newer, prettier RTS games.  Even then, we'll probably compare all of them to AOE3.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2013
												Age of Empires 3 takes an already established concept, and expands and improves it greatly.  The game features "cards" -upgrades that you can send whenever you reach another experiance tier.  Cards allow you to specialize your nations units, which are sharded between all of the nations, with one or two expections.  There are also playstyle differences between nations, with the ottomans getting free yet slow settlers, or the duty settlers costing gold instead of food.  The core gameplay is similar to AoE 2, other then this new card mechanic and trading posts.  Trading posts can be built on trade routes or on Indian villages.  Both of them are worth it.  Trade routes supply you with either resources or exp, and indian villages grant you powerful units and upgrades.  Overall, it is better then AoE 2, the card system is unique, and it is worth getting.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												AoE 3 is a pretty decent historical fiction RTS.  The game takes place mostly around the frontier days, with the exception of the Asian Dynasty pack.  I'll be talking a lot about that expansion because it's vastly different from the rest of the game.  Voice acting is decent, as are the stories, predictable though they are.  The music is catchy but highly repetitive.  85% of the game has no chill.  While it's not really all that challenging on Normal difficulty, most of the missions in the game have some kind of time or mechanical constraint that prevent them from being standard "build then destroy" affairs.  Normally I wouldn't complain about this, but themes are re-used so much that they quickly grow old.  "Oh, I don't start off with a base again."  "Oh, I can't get any villagers again."  "Oh, I don't get any resources so I have to use trading posts again."  So on and so forth.  The UI is kind of bad.  It eats up a third of my screen on 1080p, and hotkeys (of which there are many) aren't discernible via mouseovers of the buttons, so you wind up having to go back into the Options menu repeatedly if you want to use them.  Attack-move seemed not to work properly for me, which was very noticeable but not a dealbreaker.  Asian Dynasties involved very different mechanics.  Minus the UI, the production value, and a couple of buildings/progressions, it was almost different enough to be another RTS.  Some of the alterations were neat, others were bizarre.  If you play the Chinese faction during Skirmish mode, they can't build any common soldiers until they Age Up (upgrade the town hall), only siege units.  I'm sorry, what?  Whose brilliant idea was that?  You see, although there are many factions, there are really only four styles in the game:  European, Japanese, Chinese, and Indian.  It's not merely a difference in units, or buildings, but the fundamental mechanics of how they work.  Because I didn't spend a lot of hours in Skirmish mode, it's impossible for me to say if the game is balanced, but I doubt it.Something that appealed to me were the farming/shipment mechanics.  There's food, wood, coin, and a separate export resource if you're playing Asian Dynasties.  The way it's handled, however, you can build farms or receive shipments that are slow, infinite pools of any of those things.  If you run out of wild animals to hunt, build a farm or raise livestock.  If you run out of gold, plantations or rice paddies are infinite.   Wood is more difficult, but Asian Dynasties allows you to plant groves, or you can receive shipments in any case.  As a result, resource-management in the game is a lot less stressful than pretty much any RTS I've played.  Another thing that stood out is the ability to train stacks of five.  If you have the resources, you can train five troops in one building at once, and when it's finished five will pop out.  The need for multiple barracks is basically absent.  That's about everything that stood out for me.  I wouldn't pay 40 dollars for the game, wait for a decent sale, but it's definitely worth picking up for RTS fans if you don't mind historical backdrop.

What I mean is, normally DLC nowadays is required to get the full package of what the final product should've been. AoE3's Expansion Packs ARE NOT DLC. content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												This game is a classic RTS experience which can be enjoyed by anyone from a novice right up to strategic masters, I have been playing this game since release and was so impressed by the amount of times I have returned to this game after a few months break has made it worth every penny for a re-purchase on steam. If you enjoy games that envolve collecting resources and a large quantity of military and economic micromanagement then this game is for you!The multiplayer is what makes this game fantastic, the community are amazing and the battles even more impressive. The graphics even to this day are impressive so this is not a game to hold back on and is very well optimised for even the oldest and slowest of computers, if your looking for a game to keep dragging you back, this is the it!My only comments on improvement would be the reliability of the servers as of recent, there has been a few times I have failed to connect (I know they have maintenance on tuesdays, good to see they are still keeping the servers updated!), but with a good NAT type this shouldn't be an issue!My Rating - 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Great game! The improved graphics and gameplay are definitely a step up from the 2nd game in the AoE series. The ships are a lot more realistic in size, and your army sports some new equipment (namely, guns). The one thing that I don't like about this is the resources. For example, in AoE 2, you had to build a mill, and then build farms in order to gather food. You would also have to constantly resupply your farmland. In AoE 3, however, it's more of a one-time-deal; you build a mill, which comes with farmland included, and that's it. You don't have to resupply the mill with more wood to keep the farm going. You can just let it sit there for forever. Now while some people may like this, I personally, am not a huge fan of it as since it makes the game a bit TOO easy. Overall though, definitely still a good game and a worthy buy.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												As a proud AoE fanboy, I was delighted to learn a steam version had become available. AoE3 is something of a unique RTS game in that it is well balanced vanilla (prior to expansions) because of nearly a decade worth of patching. While the expansions fail to deliver as solid a RTS experience (and bump the faction count from 8 to 14), they aren't inherently bad either.I was pleased to learn also that my ESO log in and password still worked after all this time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Scarry how well this game has held up over time.  One of the best RTS that Microsoft ever put out.  It toes that fine line of not being too complex or too fast as most of these games fall into.  The allows you to set the pace and give your nation a life-like feel,    The UI is excellent and providing the information you need to keep up with your opponents while staying out of the way so you can see what your minions are up to.  I love that nations feel different, each having their own culture and quirks that gives this game a very Civilization feel.If you want to sink some time playing a game, there are few better than this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												This review is part of the vow I made to play ALL my Steam games and make short reviews of them.Age of Empires II was among the first games I ever played, and possibly the first RTS I ever played (that, or Warcraft 2).When Age of Empires III was released, I wasn't very interested, mostly because I had been pulled away from the RTS genre and that scene for a couple of years.9 years after it's initial release, I decide to get this, and boy what a great purchase. This game summarizes what I love about RTS games. Age of Empires III feels so much like a polished and new Age of Empires II, which is exactly what it should be, and at times, it doesn't even feel like this game was released in 2005.This game does most things right, having some flaws in it's gameplay since it's so old and many new games have stepped in and added to the RTS genre. Take this out of concideration (because the game still doesn't feel out-dated to me), and you have one great RTS game well worth it's price even though it's old.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												I spent years playing Age of Empires 2 + Age of Kings expansion. Since I'm not much of a RTS fan, I never liked other strategy games much, but AoE 1&2 were a pleasure for me. When AoE3 first came out, I tried it, but didn't like it. It was annoying to young me, because I was used to AoE2-like gameplay, and the sudden change was something I hated in AoE3.Years have passed, and a friend talked me into buying AoE3. We started playing it together, and it changed my opinion completely. While he is a huuuuuge fan, I wouldn't call myself a fan, but I like the game very much. It's smooth, and has some interesting advantages compared to older AoE titles.Although I'm still not a good RTS player, and I still don't really like playing RTS games, AoE3 captured my time. When played with a friend, this game is a great co-op opportunity. A variety of races, all with their unique units and strategies, makes this game what it is: A classic.Although I loved the game, I must say that Age of Empires 3: Complete Collection is not worth buying at 37€. It's too expensive, and is old enough to fall below the 15€ mark. However, if you're like me, and like sales - buy the game when its price gets low enough for your expectations.My score: 7.3/10

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												An absolute classic. Although many wouldnt consider it as good as AoE II, I find the single player campaigns and improved graphics make it far more enjoyable these days. The Warchiefs and Asian Dynasties add well balanced playable factions as well as new campaigns. There arent many people still playing the multiplayer but if you can get this game on sale the single player and skirmish mode are well worth playing. The only drawback is the price tag, £30 for a ten year old game even with the two expansion packs isnt a great deal but this bundle can be acquired cheaply on sale or from other sites.

												I can Recommend this game !!!!! For me it's a 10/10, but when you go play this game there are from my point a few requirements. 1. The multiplayer mode sucks so you have to install gameranger to play online or with friends. 2. Friends also should buy this game, because playing alone is fun, but when you play with friends its 10 times better. 3. You should have a lot of free time. You can change the game speed, but when you turn it to fast it's really boring and unrealistic. If you play at normal speed its the best and that takes for a good game 1,5-2 hours. It brought back my youth ! You don't need a brain for this game it's very easy to play. This game is great. You should definility buy it ( [/b]if you have the 3 points I said[/b] ).

												Old school realtime strategy with some pretty nice physics, building demolitions and ideas based on colonial powers. Story is trying to fill some historical gaps but is pretty simplistic and nothing to be really interested in. Playing as different civilizations and trying their unique strategies is something worth giving a shot. Especially after introducing Asian Dynasties expansion pack, Asian civilizations have some pretty interesting mechanics of building and combat.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												This is a GREAT game. a little out dated graphically, and in some ways can become somewhat repetitive. but the gameplay itself delivers a well balanced tactical strategy, that changes with every new round. Factors such as locations of resources, natural land obstacles, the strengths and weaknesses of which team you play as, which team you are playing against, and timing of every move all come in to play. If you are looking for a graphically superior game, this is not for you, but if you are looking for a well balanced game that tests your wit on decision making and productivity, this is for you!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												One of my most played favorites, goes in the hall of fame. Easy to master, lovely and balanced. Virtually zero learning curve, and the UI is a joy.The game does a lot of the work for you, while you consider small strategies. But a child can do the same.It feels complete and polished, but lacks depth and becomes extremely repetitive, however i seemed to overlook the repetition very easily.The is a large veriety of units and enough customizability to have an unspeakable number of permutations of a player's deck build, and the player can easily emboss their own personality into their army and city arrangement.You can be in any state of mind and enjoy this game, as it is relaxing and stimulating without being mentally over-taxing.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												An amazing sequel! Better graphics, better game play better everything! Age of Empires 3, has a very fun levelling system which each level you gain special cards that will give you perks for your colony. These can be customised into the players own 'deck' which then can be used while in game on multiplayer or skirmish, and it’s amazing. This immersive system really brings the thrill of a well planned strategic battle, keeping you hooked for hours. Although the multiplayer setting is extremely harsh on new players, you may have to spend half your time trying to find a lobby that will allow you to join; once you've reached a reasonable level, the game is at its peak. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I know many who love the original Age of Empires games (especially #2) hate this game or mock it for not being like the others. I grew up on Age of Empires 2 and it remains to be one of my favourite games of all time. Unlike the others I love this game as much, maybe even more, for fixing the small issues in the other games and generally making a more polished product.  The campaigns are more exciting and the combat more visceral. The expansions add many new civilizations with a whole new set of playstyles the likes of which the franchise hasn't seen before! The point of this short review is to convince people that the naysayers are wrong and that this product is the perfect swan song for Ensemble Studios.

												when i was 8, i started to play this game but later when i got little bit older, i was thinking that the (Age Of Empires 4) will come out, so i did wait and wait. year after year. but one day i was thinking that maybe the game is out, so did ask father but he didn't know anything, so i did for myself, i Searched (Age Of Empires 3) and then i finded the Developers. when i did finded the name, i Searched for them, and i finded an link, i clicked on the link. and when i started to read it. i was schocked.wikipedia:Ensemble Studios was a video game developer initially established in 1995 as an independent company by Tony Goodman, Rick Goodman and John Boog-Scott, but was acquired by Microsoft in 2001 and operated as an internal studio until 2009, when it was officially disbanded.[1] Ensemble developed many real-time strategy games, including the Age of Empires game series, Age of Mythology, and Halo Wars. In addition to game development, Ensemble Studios also made the Genie Game Engine used in Age of Empires, Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings, and Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds. The studio sold 20 million games and was worth an estimated $500 million.[2]ReleaseDate	Title	Genre1997	Age of Empires	real-time strategy1998	Age of Empires: The Rise of Rome	expansion pack1999	Age of Empires II: The Age of Kings	real-time strategy2000	Age of Empires II: The Conquerors	expansion pack2001	Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds	real-time strategy2002	Star Wars: Galactic Battlegrounds: Clone Campaigns	expansion pack2002	Age of Mythology	real-time strategy2003	Age of Mythology: The Titans	expansion pack2005	Age of Empires III	real-time strategy2006	Age of Empires III: The WarChiefs	expansion pack2007	Age of Empires III: The Asian Dynasties[3]	expansion pack2009	Halo Wars	real-time strategyCancelled	:Titan (Halo MMO)[4][5]	massively multiplayer online gameSorcerer[6]	fantasy-adventure RPGNova[6]	Wrench[6][7]	platform gameBam[6]	Agent[6]	so i'm trying to say that (Age Of Empires 4) will not come out because the Developers closed the Platform. :(Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_Studios

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												What can I say? Its AoE!!! Epic game :)I really like the nostalgie you get when playing AoE 3, this one is def. my favorite, i love that you can manage your city and build it up from start to something amazing, with the cards u unlock for the deck and stuff! I love it!It brings back memories from back in the good old days with AoE (normal) and AoE 1Thanks summer deals for a great buy! hahaBut.. I did wish there would be achievements for this, in AoE 2 there are some (a lot) but none in AoE 3 which kinda disapointed me but didnt stop me from playing thoughtThis game has lots of things going on to make cool achievements from. But that is just my opinion here :PAlso, a couple more abilities for your city would be nice too, maybe as an extentional DLC?I am not sure if this is a bug, but when i try take defend towers in my game, it gives me barracks instead, I would like to know how i can fix this because i can already buy barrack by default, so its givin me something totally useless and it says it can be used for barracks or defend towers yet i only see the barracks option when i try to build them. (its unlocked via cards in the deck)..Further as that i have no complains and i do enjoy this game a lot and i will play it more often againMuch more i cant say, its a great game if u love strategy..Thanks for making this awesome game :-)

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												If you have never played a RTS before in your life, this is the GO-TO Holy Grail of all real time stradegy games in existence. Best to catch this game when its on sale, because the 40$ seems a bit pricey for an older game. I have 1000+ hours on the game on my disk version of the game and I would have to say I have played this game more than any other game I have played. The Multiplayer is dismal due to low population on the online server, but is a perfect platform for some co-op fun vs AI. One thing that sets this game apart from the other AoE, AoM and RoN is RPG elements built in to your home city to provide a personalized way of play.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
Age of Awesome!Back in the day when this game was originally released it was often compared to the civilization series of games.In keeping with that, this is a game that has stood the test of time.So much so infact that we are what? 10 years since it's original release and the game still holds up!The multiplayer netcode is amazing, the gameplay is deep and fun and the graphics still hold up well today.The team behind this game would later go on to make the 'Orcs Must Die' series of games which are also fantastic games as well.The main goal of AoE3 is to crush all those who oppose you. Typically stragedy game stuff, but what makes the AoE series unique is that you go through 'Eras' similar to the Civ series of games however unlike those games this all happens in real time and acts as a barometer as to how deep in the (military) tech tree you are. There is a lot about this game to talk about and I can't do this game justice; The home city customization, the deck tweaking to fashion future battles to your tactics, unit formations you can switch on the fly, the explorer unit that can't die, allying with neutral locals ala city states in Civ5, years before Civ5 was even created! To Stand the Test of TimeThere are too many things about this game to like infact that is how it was designed. Greg "Ghostcrawler" Street, formally of Blizzard Entertainment said: "We worried a lot about how to innovate while staying true to the heart of the Age series. Many of the earlier features we tried were pretty different, but frankly a lot of them weren’t all that fun either. When we had iterated on an idea for too long and weren’t getting anywhere, we usually went back to what worked in our previous games. We knew our iterative design process makes great games."And what a great game it is. Even after all this time you can boot it up and have a blast playing it. Speaking of blasts, despite being a war game, it has real time physics and ragdolls so when you shoot someone with a cannon they actually and believably go flying! Your mortor shots on buildings leave entry and exits holes in buildings, you really feel like there is weight behind your unit attacks and that is very awesome. Infact the whole game, is awesome!Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

Posted: December 28, 2016
												Sadly, something about the combination of Steam, AOE III and Windows 10 x64 appears to be broken.  While I can get the two expansions to work (after being forced to enter the admin password!), the base game crashes during startup with ye olde "This program failed to start...".  The only way I managed to get the base game running is when logged in with my admin account, not something I want to do ongoing.  I've tried explicitly setting file permissions in the Steam games folder to give my normal user account full control but that didn't seem to change anything.  Also ran the usual verification process and it always reports one file failed to verify but never seems to resolve this.  Steam support pages indicate this message may be normal...Disappointed because AOE II HD edition works fine so thought AOE III would too.  Will most likely seek a refund if I can't locate a solution today.

												The "Age of Empires III: Complete Collection" includes the original game plus two expansion packs, "Age of Empires III: The Asian Dynasties" and Age of Empires III: War Chiefs", developed collaboratively by Big Huge Games and Ensemble Studios for the Games for Windows platform. I develop a Fan Patch for this game, N3O FP1.3z3N, which is available at aoe3.heavengames.comIncludes new maps, balance, spice, new unique features, without changing the way the game is played!Has been tested by some of the best players in the community, and aims to achieve the highest regard. Developed over 2 1/2 years, it should give every player a new feel, just like when Warchiefs expansion came out. It is large enough to be considered an Expansion Pack by itself, except that it comes free of charge!On top of this, it includes a deadly new AI, highly skilled in 2v2 matches. If you are a fan of the Age Series, Buying Age of Empires III this is a must. If you are further very adament about this game, I would highly suggest trying out the Fan Patch. If not the Patch, then for its AI player! regards,murdilator

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Offers a slightly different play-style than in Age of Empires II. One of the biggest changes to the game is the resources and resource-gathering process. There are only three resources instead of four.  Your resource-gathering does not have to be micro-ed as much as in previous games because in the later ages, food and gold do not run out. Wood can also be continuously generated through factories, shrines, trading-posts, etc. This allows the player to focus more on their military. The nearly-unlimited supply of resources means that later battles do not turn into "trash-fights" induced by the lack of gold/wood. Overall, a very good game but overpriced without any discounts. Wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												You guys have got to get this! Its friggin amazing! The multiplayer has brilliant progression system. (selecting special abilities from a deck of unlocked cards to personalise your play style.) The building in this is quite unique in that you can place your structures anywhere, there is no 'grid' placement. The destruction is entirely satisfying; watching cannons blow appart a building and the peices cascade over the landscape BLEW MY MIND! No more generic, repeated destruction animation! The customisation of your home city was an a great surprise! A fantastic reward for leveling up and a great backdrop for the menu screens. Additionally I dont really mind the fewer races, as there are so many units in each. What I would have liked to see is the unit formations buttons from age of empires II, allowing you to alter the positions of your army better. Additionally the stance buttons to prevent your army running off would be great to implement. 4.2 out of 5, im addicted already!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Age of Empires III is, without a doubt, an RTS classic. Though perhaps not as popular or widely played as its predecessor, AoE3 deserves recognition for its gutsiness and charm.Gameplay is comparable to other RTS titles with the notable exception of the home city and experience mechanics. Prolonged games and even campaigns will accrue experience points that grant resource, tech, and military benefits to players based on their customized home cities. The ability to level up one's supply support and farm experience through side objectives and battles adds an entirely new dimension to the economic and military struggles that have typically comprised RTS experiences.Aesthetically, the game is quite enjoyable. While it is a tad old, the textures and visual resources manage to be reasonable (though cutscenes are frequently laughable in quality). The ability to zoom in and out on the game has made a return from Age of Mythology, making combat engagements easier to watch and enjoy up close. The soundtrack is iconic and will get stuck in your head after only a few games.The campaigns are what make the complete collection really shine. While deathmatches and skirmishes are entertaining, the at-times-poorly-written-but-still-enjoyable story of the Black family over six generations establishes a sort of epic within the game that players will find themselves driven to progress through. Lovable and hateable characters such as the black family, Billy Holme, Kanyenke, Major Cooper, and more color the games often cheesy but still fantastic story. The relative historical accuracy of the game makes is engaging and watching characters such as George Washington, Simon Bolivar, and General Custer being woven into the story is quite amusing. An expectation emerges as to who the story will involve next. Once players get bored with the stories of the Black family (in the original game and the War Chiefs expansion), they can turn their eyes to several shorter stories of Japanese, Chinese, and Indian heroes in the Asian Dynasties expansion, allowing for a whole new Age of Empires experience.Most faults within the game are fairly minor and don't impede playing extensively. The most irritating problem comes with managing large groups of units and selecting individual soldiers out of said groups. This can be accomplished much easier with hotkeys, but it's a lot of effort for such an activity. Unit speeds, managing artillery, and certain little ticks with targeting, action queueing, and attack orders are also frustrating at times, though not game breaking. The pacing of the Japanese campaign in the Asian Dynasties expansion is also notably broken, although it arguably allows for a wider range of deck and home city customisation.Age of Empires III is, in brief, yet another respectable and pleasant RTS game from Ensemble Studios. The gameplay echoes older titles while incorporating novel elements to breath new life into the series, and the story is engrossing and captivating in much the same way that Age of Mythology (and, to an extent, not Age of Empires II) was. AoE3's knack for good storytelling and gameplay that is quick and easy to pick up overcomes its small mechanical faults and sometimes poor campaign pacing to present an enchanting and memorable game that is definitely worth playing, and the variety of campaigns provided by the various expansions will ensure the player does just that for a considerable amount of time. Welcome to the New (or perhaps the old, as is the case with Morgan Black and the Japanese campaign) World!

Posted: January 7, 2015
												I've had this game and previous titles in the series since the discovery age (pun intended) but was unable to play multiplayer until i purchased it on steam, the multiplayer is so much more in depth and unexpected than single player. The only 2 things that annoy me and they REALLY annoy me is that, It takes a very long time to find opponents using "quick" search which i guess can be explained by the small playerbase, and in game browser you will always end up with at least 1 pro on your team or the enmy which will single handedly win the game for that team, even if you change the title of the lobby to something like "noobs only" some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ will still join. The other annoyance is that if one person is lagging either due to low FPS or bad internet all players will lag to the same extent or even more, which is very frustrating to experience with a high end system and good internet.Overall  I would recommend if you have played the singleplayer enough and want to play multiplayer, and think you are good enough to not be smashed by the pros, i would not buy for the singleplayer aspect though as the campaign is quick and the skirmish with bots get's repetitive fairly quickly.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
OverallThis game is honestly one the best, no... I'm sorry, THE BEST RTS game I have ever played. I liked this better than other games like dota and smite (though I am more of a historical strategy nerd) but I think that the mechanics of building buildings and being able to control of all of your units amazing. I would say that this game is a little overpriced, and that's why I got it during a sale.DLCI like the complete edition because playing as the native americans or the asians is very different from the way that you play the Europeans, yet I feel that each country is still pretty balanced. The campaign is actually very fun to play, too.Age of Empires III versus Age of Empires II Now, if you are trying to decide between AoE II or AoE III, I would recommended this game (AoE III) only if you haven't played AoE II before. I've heard that this game is different from AoE II in ways that the people who play AoE II don't like, but if you have never been exposed to AoE II before you will find that the pros outweigh the cons of playing this game because most people who like AoE II mostly like it out of nostalgia.ConclusionIn the end, this game and Civilization V are the only games I play frequently on Steam. So, if you enjoy strategy games of historical themes, get this one of you like RTS or get Civilization V if you like turn-based games.P.S. As for you AoE II fans, well just get AoE II because AoE III tends to disappoint the lot of you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												I'm really only posting this to encourage others to buy AOE3 > AOE2. AOE3 has better graphics and the gameplay feels more streamlined like other modern RTS. There are distinct build orders and you'll feel satisified completing a fish boom trurtle against a rush player, and on the other hand cavalary rushes will feel different than inifantry rushes so there is a lot of replayability regardless of play style.The overall game is similar to older AOE installments with a Rock Paper Scissor style of unit balance. The same type of units are shared across multiple civilations so its easy to understand what units you'll need to overcome your opponets army. The resorce collection is more invovled and extremely engaging compared to other RTS. Resource collection is simplified from AOE2 but still demands that players understand map control to secure future resources for continued military production. I can't compliment the resource gathering system in AOE enough its the main reason I feel this game has stood the test of time.Trading posts and deck building add dynamic map centric objectives, there is a lot of negativity around the card system and yes its true most players will use the same cards for the first 1-3 shipments, in late game they provide diversity and allow you to specialize into specific tech choices. If you're coming back to Age of Empires from Starcraft or another modern RTS than AOE3 will have the best feel for you. 10-20minute games compared to 40-60minute games in AOE2. The gameplay is more streamlined and build orders are unique and rewarding. And if you're the player that enjoys long turtle games they are still 100% possible and as I stated feel more rewarding when defending challenging pushes from your opponet.Happy Hunting.

content:
Posted: January 11
												I wanted to like this game. However, Age of Empires® III: Complete Collection is a game that simply doesn't meet what I remember as a child and the awesome gameplay that I used to have to load from a disc (and still do own). As nice as the visuals in this game are, the gameplay simply is sub-par and I was bored very quickly into it, unlike the fast-paced action of the original game. In addition, Decks feel like a clunky and unnecessary addition to the game. The benefits they provide are not neglectible, so you can't enjoy the game as is; you have to play with decks in order to not be left behind, which is something I find unnecessary and tedious as an old player of the game.This game is not worth it. Simply put, Age of Empires II is a better game, and for good reason. It is the same price as this one. Once I get the money, I will be purchasing AoE II: HD Edition with all of its DLCs, which is ultimately the same price as this. So go buy AoE II: HD Edition, not this game. Unless you really like the deck building, or a slightly more relaxed gameplay, this version is not for you. As an RTS, this game is not bad, but as an Age of Empires game, I would take my money elsewhere.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												One of the best strategy games i've played, also just an amazing game in general.There are many civilizations to choose from, even can play as native americans. I've spent numerous hours on this game, almost 300 alone on the steam version and many more on the disc version. The online multiplayer is still enjoyable till this day, With an overall good community and hours of intense battles among many.+Good graphics for its time+Overall good AI+Soundtrack is nice+Many Civilizations to choose from with each their own advantages+Easy to learn controls-A few bugs that can be annoying but not drastic

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
OverallThis game is honestly one the best, no... I'm sorry, THE BEST RTS game I have ever played. I liked this better than other games like dota and smite (though I am more of a historical strategy nerd) but I think that the mechanics of building buildings and being able to control of all of your units amazing. I would say that this game is a little overpriced, and that's why I got it during a sale.DLCI like the complete edition because playing as the native americans or the asians is very different from the way that you play the Europeans, yet I feel that each country is still pretty balanced. The campaign is actually very fun to play, too.Age of Empires III versus Age of Empires II Now, if you are trying to decide between AoE II or AoE III, I would recommended this game (AoE III) only if you haven't played AoE II before. I've heard that this game is different from AoE II in ways that the people who play AoE II don't like, but if you have never been exposed to AoE II before you will find that the pros outweigh the cons of playing this game because most people who like AoE II mostly like it out of nostalgia.ConclusionIn the end, this game and Civilization V are the only games I play frequently on Steam. So, if you enjoy strategy games of historical themes, get this one of you like RTS or get Civilization V if you like turn-based games.P.S. As for you AoE II fans, well just get AoE II because AoE III tends to disappoint the lot of you.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												To me its theme is not as fun as Age of Mythology (I like fantasy better than westerns) but came later so you can expect better graphics. It is an old style rts with an easy campain; though it is long enough with the add-ons from the complete collection. The nice touch here is the home city you can level over the game (it will take many games to get all the upgrades for a single nations) and the variety of civilisations available in the complete collection.Definitely a good game to play if it goes on sale and you want to try a game in the Age Of series (this was the last release). If you like fantasy better and don't mind older graphics go for Age of Mythology insead. Though you may find better / nicer looking games

												The FitnessGram(TM) Pacer Test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues. The 20 meter pacer test will begin in 30 seconds. 												Good game, AI is kinda trash though but it's still pretty fun to play against and you can always play multiplayer as there are still people playing. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												AoE 3 with its addons is a fine little edition created by ensemble.im not one for writing long as hell reviews so ill keep it simple and informative.Pros:- Stays faithful to AoE mechincs- Interesting way to customise your chosen nation in mp/skirmish with cards- Interesting stories in the numerous campaigns- looks pretty- cheesy but funny in game voice overs of leadersCons :- I felt the maps were small- Combat can be rather onesided for or against you depending on tech- Cant build a wall over trade router but you can in tutorial (dafuq?)- AI can be turtle like or rush like theres no real balance or intelligence to it- Multiplayer is deadOverall:Id say buy it if you a fan of the other AoE titles. If youve never played AoE before then again buy it it will give you something new to try. Being an age old AoE fan my oppinion is biased but i do like and i would reccomend it for those who like RTS and looking for something different to play7/10

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
 Have been a massive fan of age of empires all my life and brought this game as soon as it was realeased. I have played thousands of hours on the disk version of this game. I brought it on steam to purchase the DLCs and experience them. They are just as good as the base game; but i always go back to my personal favourite: the french! Putting that aside Age of Empires III ensures that the Age of Empires is one of the best RTS series' on the market. The new card and shipment system has brought in an extra level of strategy. The cards can be instrumental between a massive victory and a crushing victory, and i have often been involved in battles decided by who has the better cards. They can be the decider in who rushes the quickest, or who has the strongest military, or assist in establishing a stable econonomy with resource cards. Trade routes and native training buildings also bring in more strategy, with the ability to train cheap, effective native troops who have no impact on your population (but still have a build limit). Trade routes pretty much replace and improve on relics and allow you to collect more than just gold from them and can be a good resource provider.Units have been improved from 2 and nearly every unit has a strength against another type of unit, but for every strong unit, there is always a counter of some sorts. Although unique units from castles has been removed, you will find that in the base game, some civilisations will have access to some units while not having access to others.Artillery has been improved (organers from AOEII would destroy every unit in a battle, friend or foe alike) and the artillery can play a much bigger role in deciding the outcome of a battle.Ship Combat has also been refined and has become more fun to engage in, with access to ships that can train units, and having more than one ranged DPS ship designed specifically to destroy other enemy ships from a distance.Overall, Age of Empires III is a great game and is my personal favourite out of the series. I would recconmend it to new players and veterans of the genre who have played the first 2 and are looking for something new. Although be warned, stratetgy masters from the first 2 games will also have to learn the new mechanics; you cannot just pick up where you left off in AOEII and think you'll be just as good in AOEIII, and vice versa. It will feel alot different when you go back and play the first 2 games. But enough rambling on, i greatly recconmend this game to anyone 8.5/10

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Age of Empires III is more than just a game, it's the latest generation in a legacy of great games. It is the exampe of what games should be like in this genre. It still sets the bar for excellence. I come back to in continually to pop on and do part of a campaign or a quick squirmish. The online multiplayer is a bit lacking, but it appears they are working on new servers for it. Mainly there arent many people playing it, and it can be difficult to connect. Hopefully they will continue to develop and work on this great name for some time (and one day we'll see the much anticipated Age of Empires IV). This is a must buy. I've played every type of game there is to play for a couple of decades now. Just like Link to the Past and MGS, you will return to this game to remind yourself of what you love about it.

number of helpful: 18 of 38 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												Age of Empires III is less of a successor and more of a reimagining of Age of Empires II. Limited, level-based, and less challenging than AoE2, it's not easy to fairly compare the two games. It feels like the AoE3 developers never really played AoE2 much, but were fond of playing the Warcraft series and based it off of that. In every game you get an "Explorer" which isn't much more than a glorified villager that never permanently dies. Your choices for game setup are 1-vs-1 team or a free-for-all. There are no in-game alliances, all your units and buildings are limited in number, and your max pop is about 200. Oh, and your home city can only earn 30,000 xp each game.Despite these limitations, resources (Wood, Food, Gold; stone is nonexistant) couldn't be easier to gather. Buildings such as Farms, Rice Paddies, etc. offer unlimited free resources after building for one low cost.The goal of this game is to level up your home city and earn "cards", shipments you recieve at no cost from your home city. You try each civilization out, level them up, and if you don't have a fiance, friends, or a family member to play with, you never play this again for a very long time.If you like Age of Empires II, DON'T buy this game unless it's dirt cheap. You will try it, play it, tire of it, and return to Age of Empires II.5.5/10

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												I haven't had much call to write negative reviews thus far - I habitually only choose to say stuff about things I like, which would make my mum proud I guess - but duty compells me to speak out against Age of Empires III, and sundry, on account of the hideous let down it proved to be with regards to the duty of all sequels to take the best parts of earlier titles in a series and strive to improve them further.Age of Empires is one of the few series in which I can honestly claim to have a comprehensive base of experience in on which to form opinions (TES, Deus Ex, Civilization and MGS spring to mind as other examples), in fact I don't think there is any game series which I have a more complete relationship to than this one. (I might say Vanilla WoW had the biggest impact on me, for better or worse, but that's not a series is it)So this might be a bit rant'y. But I will try to also make it instructive.This game is a massive betrayal and letting down of everything that made the opening two titles of the series, and their expansions, so fantastic.Starting at the beginning: Age of Empires. Released in, I believe, 1998, this was one of the first full computer games that I ever attempted to play, since my family got it as part of a deal for a new PC, our first modern computing system. I wouldn't say that I played it, per se. I was a bit of a dumbass then and it took me a few months at least to realize that the trial version game I had been playing over and over again actually existed on the same computer in full version, if only I would insert the play CD located near the computer. The trial version however informed my relationship with Age of Empires, and informed what I came to really expect from Age of Empires: The mini-campaign we enjoyed (indeed, I believe it was a single mission - practically at least this is what it was because as a total nubcake I believe I never actually beat the mission, though I got extremely good at playing it) traced the birth of the Hittite culture, from gathering food from a carcass or two to entering the Bronze Age and raiding one - perhaps two? Broad Swordsmen to take the fight to our dastardly red foes.The game was about history, it was informative, the graphics were detailed, the music lovely, the missions loooong and the scope for imagination limitless.Then of course we all know what happened when Age of Empires II came out. I first caught wind of AoE2 when I was outside a PC shop in a shopping centre food court and I saw some lucky so-and-so playing the Joan of Arc campaign opening mission inside the window. As someone who had loved Age of Empires for so long (a couple of years at least) this game represented a quantum leap in graphics, detail, narrative, storytelling, scripting - everything! It blew my mind.But it was still about history. It was still informative - even more so - the graphics were so detailed that even now 16 years later they are still gorgeous to me, the music was even more lovely and the missions seemed bigger, longer, but also more accessible.Age of Empires II: The Conquorers Expansion was the final shining badge of honour on the series, the ultimate RTS game. Adding a few tweaks to the fantastic Age of Empires II model - one click garrissoning, farm build queus - everything went into overdrive with the addition of the Aztecs and some other South American civilzations, as well as the introduction 'closer to home' as it were of such slightly less antiquated groups such as the Spanish or Koreans. The Hun campaign, following Atilla, would prove to be the most immersive and replayable of all the narrative-driven campaigns, supplanting Joan of Arc and Ghengis Khan from the base game.So finally we get to what happened when Age of Empires III came out.Well, initially it looked like another fantastic rebirth of this timeless, epic series. I deduced this from a raft of gorgeous screenshots - never before or since has a historic setting been so beautifully presented. Turtled sunned themselves on logs, Native Americans rode dustily across a distant plane, Mayan temples towered above misty swamps. These screenshots can all still eb found online if one looks hard enough through the google image results. It was inevitable, I thought, a done deal: Age of Empires III was going to be the most beautiful, expansive, historically absorbing, atmospheric RTS game ever created. I was so proud of my series.So what did I get instead? Well to prevent you from feeding money to this pile of excrement I will spoil it for you (at least partially).The long missions and giant maps have been replaced by crap maps with ridiculous scaling and a totally inadequate zoom range, as well as the addition of a ton of third-party NPC settlements and the like designed to aid the flow of quick gameplay. The graphics that looked so unbelievable - like Crysis made into an RTS - in early screenshots lost entire fields of polygons, lost textural acuity by the boatload, giving us something that looked like a cross between Age of Mythology and freaking Warrior Kings. The gameplay, which had looked pacific, ephemeral and deliberate in the screenshots turned into a pile off bullspit, with hero characters and wonky missions structures completely doing away with micromanagement or preparations. Your villages didn't even walk anymore, you just sent them to gathering places and they just stood there feeding you resources. What the hell does this even MEAN?But the biggest sin of all is what they did to the historical roots of the series: They took a pewp all over them. You wanted to relive the conquests and dying resistance of the Aztecs in beautiful, out of this world graphics and scale? Too bad. You get some coque and bull story about frigging jesuit knights searching for the fountain of youth. This spoiler is but a taste of the range and depth of the ridiculous plots that we get shoved down our throats by this ridiculous title, which ends up having our chief enemy during our South American adventure being the trucking Ottoman Empire.Don't even get me started on the massive gimmick and gameplay-hastener that is the home city concept.No. Don't get this game. Get the AoE2 HD bundle available elsewhere on Steam. This game is god awful. You will get more fun out of Rise of Nations - a lot more fun - or indeed Age of Mythology which was excused from the sings of this title by being specifically set in a mythological universe.I detest this game, and if ever someone takes the time to craft the game that this one was meant to be then you'd better believe I'm gonna play it's donkey off.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
9/10NOTE: The hours on record are inaccurate because i've owned a pre-steam retail copy. The Age of Empires series has always been a personal favorite of mine. Dating back to the first AOE I i've been always astonished by the overall gameplay experience this game delivers. The AI system is very well written and, depending on the difficulty, will always provide a challenge. This game is often compared to Starcraft II yet there is a lot of differences between them. In Starcraft I always found myself rushing and trying to be the best, and if you were bad at the game, you were in for a lot of stress. But in AOE players can find servers with their own skill level which makes this game one of my favorite strategy games. In my opinion, you don't HAVE to play online like most competitive games. This game actually has a very good Skirmish mode where you go against bots. It may seem boring but if you give it a chance, it will not disappoint you. As for aesthetics, the graphics are great considering it was a game made in 2009 but this is just a small factor since the game's mechanics draw you away from noticing. There is rarely glitches, units walk with great animation, and the battle scenes have you urging to see what team will win. The only downfall the game has is that there is no cross-platform multiplayer support and it lacks an intriguing storyline. It is common for an AOE game to have a blan or boring storyline. And you can see that when looking at its predecessors. But don't let this change your opinion. The game wasn't really made with a basis on heartwarming or intense storyline experiences but more of a play-with-friends or AI and just have a great time.Overall, I wish they made a AOE 4. Their progression from each Age of Empires have only been big leaps in the gaming industry. But I will happily settle for AOE 3 and look forward to playing it many, many years from today. If you are in to strategy games like StarCraft, Warcraft, and Command & Conquer, this is no doubt a game worth adding to your arsenal!

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Marginally a thumbs down, and for valid reasons. Its a familiar game genre that is easy to pick up and play from scratch, and i remember enjoying this first time round, on old low-res CRT screens.  It is so close to the Settlers that most people will already know intuitively what to do.  HOWEVER...and it's a big however. It's curious that the game hasn't yet been patched or updated to play in HD res, so if you've invested in a thumping good HD flatview monitor you'll have a somewhat pixellated view whichever resolution you opt for, or maybe just stick with AOE 2 with its twee retro graphics.  The control GUI takes up far too much of the screen area, and a lot of features on the map are heaped close together and appear confused.  Things you get used to during play.  I doubt they'll patch or update this version, more likely they'll go for AOE 3 HD and get us to buy it all over again for the higher screen resolution compatibilities.  I scratch my head at Steam, for not making these things clear in the game info.  Getting to the point where they've abandoned any pretence at quality control and are happy to sell us anything.Final analysis: a glib good-clean-family-fun game by the Bill Gates Empire, except that families don't play games on computers, individuals play games on computers.  The demographic doesn't exist beyond film and TV.  They worked on assumptions back in "those days".  Now we know better and this would have been a slightly grittier game if they'd woken up ten years earlier.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
												I don't think I should have to explain why Age of Empires is fun, so instead:Homemade Tortilla (for 8 servings)Prep : 30 minsCook : 25 minsIngredients :- 1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour- 3/4 teaspoon salt- 1/4 teaspoon baking powder- 1/4 cup vegetable shortening- 1/2 cup hot waterDirections :1. Whisk flour, salt, and baking powder together in a large bowl. Add vegetable shortening and work into flour mixture using a pastry cutter until it resembles coarse crumbs.2. Form a well in the middle of flour mixture and mix in hot water. Work flour and water mixture together with a fork and transfer to a cutting board.3. Knead until a smooth, soft dough is formed, about 3 minutes. Add more flour if dough is too sticky.4. Place more flour on cutting board, cover dough with bowl, and let rest for 15 minutes.5. Cut ball of dough into eight equal parts and cover until needed.6. Roll out balls of dough either by hand or with a tortilla press.7. Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Place flattened tortilla in skillet and cook until it begins to bubble, about 1 minute. Flip tortilla over and cook for an additional minute. Flip again and cook for 1 more minute. Repeat with remaining dough.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Simplifying my gripes with the game:-No formations like in AOE2, not talking about tactics, actual formations.-Poor pathfinding, units get stuck and slowed down very often.-Clunky, busy UI. Hotkey banners get clicked on accidentally often. Too much space wasted at top, everything crammed at bottom.-Unbalanced units makes games often end up as a rock paper scissors with civilizations. Artillery is extremely OP and easy to win with, even against their counters.-Not very many civilizations.-Campaign plays completely differently than multi. It's also campy and the missions jump from too easy to too difficult.-Card system breaks games.Plenty of reasons why AOE3 is not as fondly remembered as AOE2. The real talent left Ensemble to make Rise of Nations.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												Okay so before i start this very short review i would like to note that though i only have 3 hours in this game i have played roughly 200+ offline in the past, before it was on steam. Also note that i am comparing this to AOE2. Okay so let me start with the plus's of this game.+Better Graphics+Bigger mapsThats just about all i can think of for plus's.When it comes to the minus's i'd like to think i have a fair comparison when looking back to aoe2 and this game. So this games "RTS" system is probably the most unqiue and bull♥♥♥♥♥♥excuse for a game under the genre... The games AI is broken as ♥♥♥♥, the level up system is ♥♥♥♥ing stupid and dont even get me started about the varity of teams. A small thing that made AOE2 unique was the randomised team names where in AOE3 it uses actual historyical figures to play as, all of which are terribly voiced over. I can't stress enough that this game is a watered down yet stale game.I cant recommend this AOE game because it hardly even stands up as an AOE. PS: Yes AOE2 is one of my favorate games.

content:
Posted: February 13
												I come from a long background with AOE1 and 2, so by comparison, this game was an overwhelming disappointment. The game is, for one, not easy to just pick up and learn. The traditional control scheme of gathering resources while building cities and armies is skewed, removing a large part of resources and troop-building altogether. Most of your income is transported from the 'homeland' to you over the course of a match, which makes sense from a colonial standpoint, but makes games painfully slow, leaves you feeling significantly less in-control of your empire, and narrows down the game into 2-3 playstyles regardless of your civilization choice. And while the game's visuals are nice, the scaling up of buildings and units alongside the 3D view leaves the maps feeling much smaller and minimizes the emphasis on careful exploration that was a landmark of previous games.AOE3 is, essentially, not reminiscient of its predecessors in any way, and can hardly be called a continuation/conclusion of the franchise: The fact that AOE2 is STILL getting support and new, regular DLCs today while this game is largely left in the dust, speaks to how few gamers made the transition.

content:
Posted: February 12
												I have this game since 2006 and been playing it FOR DECADES ...so...(The degradation of the game  Multiplayer experience has reached really high levels):ppl hackingdisconnecting and so on..It's a shame..Great package, great memories, not so great achievement by Microsoft, Ensemble Studios that closed downwards an "age" of strategy with this game and its expansion that have nothing to do with AOE II and "The Conquerors" which instead made history (as we all know).This game (AOE III and the expansions (2) ) has reached today a level of acidity also online that can't be called longevity, it' can't be called such at all.The missing of patches (only available today via Eso Community - an unofficial community - and that allows to play with a few players, mostly skilled ones), the fact that ESO in origin chose to put this HORRENDOUS thing of the "military ranks" that makes the game totally trivial and perfect for "immature behaviour" when looking for a match (online), or when approaching an other player, and many more WRONG doings have destroyed the future and crippled my experience.It's TRILLION LIGHT YEARS FAR from MSN GAMING ZONE, if some of you know (I doubt it since most of readers are too young) was a perfect free open space to meet and play randomly with ANYONE. Here there are classes, you can't actually get to play with all, you will be able to play just with a part of the people online, for a lot of reasons that are totally unreasonable. (ranking is one of the issues... the rest is Human failure).This game is a drug as I love strategy, but for sure there is much better then this as a strategy game.I raccomend it if you are just newbies as now it's full of new players just crashing against each other in matches (conscripts, vs concripts, privates vs privates).The "middle class player" (sergeant) is missing, and then there are the strong players (a "small" niche) only playing against each other. Actually playing with other players you don't know today is like playing slot machines, they can be ranked as you want but then in game there is zero respect of the colleague and of the enemy, I mean verbal attack are daily made, there is anyway a total unbalance for some civs that if you don't use will just turn against you.If you use French and Japan you have a big chance to win this game, Russia is strong too, the rest are just "down graded".Some players use the treaty mode, which requests for long long time as you need from 20 to 40 minutes, where you can't actually attack the opponent. (for me it is a waste of time)  why?It's simple. As mentioned above the Civilization (which are quite a big number) came with 2 expansions plus the original retail AOE III: of these the Asians are actually the most unbalanced (strong in relation to the others) as also is today (and stays) French (of the european batch, the original group of civs) in particular (why? Becuase of the units, they can't simply be countered, especially under a constant state of Lagging at the time where these units come in handy (late age around after 20 minutes of game) ... and you can't micro, you can't actually manage to stop them... they will cripple any possible advantage you have. I don't wanna point the finger against a civ or something in partiucular, the game is simply not balanced.The best way to balance it is just play it RUSHING (attacking at the beginning). And this happens especially in team game.The only way to play this game is knowing everything of it, and just playing what is stronger, you will just win all the time if you know how to play or have a better deck of cards (Ah yes... I forgot, this game flows as a card games as you have a deck you can choose to interact with as it was the home land sending you help that supports you)....Today the knowledge of the game has got so far from players that they (this is somehow a good thing and a bad thing) find ways to exploit the weak spots of every civ or the strong points so that today everybody knows (BOOSTING THE PREDICTABILITY of the game) that if you play Japanese against Dutch or French against dutch for example, the former(s) will have a better chance to win against the latter(s).In fact there are parts of the game you can't actually use today against skilled players because they know how to walk over that easily, it's just the game that is unbalanced and even if you improve all the units and are at the last age, there won't be a way (if they improved all the units to counter some of them), There simply isn't a way.I can mention a dozen of facts that would just make you understand this game is not OPEN. You already know when you start who is pratically going to win and lose.So, not just because of the PR (percentage of winning - which after all is not such a bad thing and it is a "ranking" precision information added to the already disturbing military ranking - which you start from constript and goes, private, lance corporal, corporal, sergeant, master sergeant, 1 liutenant, 2 liutenant, and so on...) but also because of the attitude of many today worst players still online, with no respect of other people time, (when playing in team with them), nor respecting them even as "opponent" after or during the game (If someone drops during the game do not expect someone else going out to balance a 3 v 2 where one has dropped out of connection... not at all... we will just play 3 vs 2 ... - that's the honor there is in these people and game ... disturbing and disgusting).Do not hid behind the fact that "You are a noob" or "you don't know how to lose" or "it's just a game".It's not just a game, we are here together to respect each other.And this rule yes, does really apply to this game community too and to real life in general.So if you wanna play, then play it, I suggest you to do it 1 v 1 .. until you find friends, with which you can rely on, you have alchemy with and you maybe can talk on Team speak or something like that.otherwise you will just waste your time on random team gaming. It's just a waste of your precious life.The predictability of the game is one of the major flows (and a game that really was fun I have played maybe 1 a year and I play a lot! ... Most of the best games are when you play with skilled players, it's fun because you can rely and if you play hard you can get the price of that effor which is THE FUN you get from the match.Otherwise a big NO NO for this game,Unbalanced CivilizationsPredictabilityRanking system that is really heavy over the human factor, self imposing, not allowing a normal exchange between people, which are not users or A.I. ... we are HUMANS. (I do understand why ESO closed, they do not understand nothing with Marketing, anthropology and much more if they chose to put in place such a public system online dividing people instead of uniting them).LaggingNew Gen. Gamers behaviour (zero honor, zero respect)All this said in an haphasarded way ... maybe but very clear to me. You play this game you just will be stressed if you do not have friends to play it with, if you believe in the game as a balalanced one (you are dead wrong).French are not the only ones, Japanese can't actually be blocked, raided, you can also use some civs against Japs, French mainly and Russians and they will constantly be tore to pieces.It's not about being a noob, this game doesn't allow to be fun for all, it has a steep learning curve at some point and for the basics of amicality, respect, fluidity, humanity in the game totally fails to deliver.Buy at your own risk.(Ah, btw, I have hundreds of hours on this game, just check on Elo rating AOE - _Tomahawk_ .. that's all).Thanks for reading the review, comment, or feedback.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Unfortunately given its normal price, one shouldn't pay it unless you've never played it and want to play it ALL through, otherwise the costs kind of outway the benefits in this case.Why?1. Maps are very creative don't get me wrong, but the circular world doesn't really work and restricts some maps to feeling smaller than they should be.  Although when compared to AOE2 this isn't really a valid arguement, you can't create your own maps in terms of customising so most of the maps aren't great in my opinion.2.  IF YOU ARE GETTING THIS GAME FOR MULTIPLAYER, CONSIDER MY ISSUE!  I've had numerous trouble with the SOE servers which periodically times out on me resulting in a ragey loss not due to my incompitence in the game.  I assume this is their server hosting related (which unless you live in the Northern Hemisphere then you'll likely struggle to find a unlaggy game), although unless you playing with friends you could struggle with the same problems as I have.3. Singleplayer is interesting, but as to if it can really hold your interest or if its challenging enough then you might have to do your own research yourself.  I personally enjoyed it, but I wouldn't recommend it for this alone (thankfully its the complete edition so you'll have more than the base game mission series to run through).4. Graphics are nice and should be able to run on any computer made since 2007 I would say, although as I found out later its just as good as AOE1 in terms of content and playablility.5. How units are created really bothers me for some reason in this game.  Although its nice not to have to click 40 times for 40 units on a building, spitting out 10 soldiers and only 1 'demoman' hasnt really made me any better off especially because depending on what civilisation you pick only a handful of units are worth having.  Oh, and before I forget about population issues your not allowed to build trading posts anyway or exceed a certain number of houses either!Sure get it on sale if you really want to have a bash, but don't get your hopes up too far because many other games made 10 years ago in my opinion deserve more attention or have better pro's than this game can offer (sadly).

Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												I bought this game at a discounted price of $7 which is the only way you should pick this game up since the price will match the content in this game.Age of Empires 3 is a joke without any DLC you have like 4 or 5 nations to choose from and a few maps, which would be ok if the game was not $40.Next, this "RTS" game has many issues with the single player and multy player, first the multy player since thats the easist to cover, it doesn't work, like at all, i tried to get a game going with a friends since as I said I had bought it for $7 so if it sucked I wouldn't be too mad, but it just doesn't work at all which makes me mad, I would have been fine with there were some connection issues or latency since the games so old but no, just doesn't even start.Secondly the single player which is divided into Skirmish mode and story, the story I found lack luster and not as interesting as AoE 2 stories, and secondly Skirmish mode, this mode got wrecked, Maps are way too small and we all know how Age of Empires AI was and still is SUPER agressive, well small maps just make that worse since you now have to rush around with your villagers to gather resources to get to the next age before the AI does and comes over with cannons and kills you.Lastly is the card system, while I enjoy it because it makes the game slightly more easy to new and old comers alike, that still does not give this game a pass for punishingly hard AI and really no totorial since you would think that you would get one in the story right, not really their idea of a totorial is just throw them into the heat of battle and tell them how to make units, what building makes what unit, and the time and resouces it takes to make said unit, not what unit is best to kill what unit, you kind of have to go off common sense with that one, like samurai (you only have samurai if you get the asian DLC) what do samurai kill the fastest because it's not infantry like you think it would be, but they seem to kill light cavlery the fastest.all in all if you pick this game up at a discounted prices like I did you can't complain too much but if you do pick this up keep in mind that this will be a solo game with some seriously cut content, but if your looking for a game like this and don't care about price get Age of Empires 2, it has more content, less DLC and is like $20 cheaper.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This wouldn't be a bad game, 15 years ago, and I understand it is an older game. However, given it's initial release date was 2005, I am going to review it's gameplay based on the common expectation of features, and it's current playable status based on compatability with modern computers.Compairing this to standard RTS of the time that had been released prior to this one, starcraft and warcraft, it is seriously lacking. Units have no special controls that were standard by 2005 such as attack move, patrol, ect. your only option is attack and move, and hope your units are capable of figuring out what to attack.The storyline is great, it's interesting and engaging, however quirky, and without adding spoilers, it tries to be historically accurate as far as timeline and unit names, however it is like the entire story and themes were created by someone who never achieved a higher grade than C- in history.The hero unit voices are so repetitive it will make you want to not use them just so you do not have to hear them. As far as current compatability, this game works fine with current Windows 7 8 10, however my biggest issue is the size of the interface, it seems like despite the game being made compatible for larger screens, it didn't scale correctly, which makes the entire gameplay feel very claustrophobic on larger screans (higher than 1080).I would give this game a 4/10, but most would rate it higher, it's worth trying if interested and you can get over the above mentioned problems, but for me it was just too many announces to really make it fun to play.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2012
												Age of Empires III only really has one problem. It's not an Age of Empires game. Gone are the truly massive maps where layers upon layers of walls and fortress barricaded your way to the enemy stronghold. Gone are the contest for resource locations where everything from half-naked barbarians to well dressed musketeers would throw themselves into certain death just to save that last stone mine.It is a game that has lost any sense of character and identity. The combat is a garbled mess without any use for formations, flanking or even tactics. The maps are small and boring. The campaigns bring nothing new to the table and the units are nothing but rock, paper, scissor stand-ins.Age of Empires was a great series and this is the game that killed it. Age Of Empires III is a shell of a game and why anyone would chose this game over Age of Kings is beyond me. It simply isn't worth it.
