number of helpful: 13 of 39 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Personally I never owned AoE3 growing up and coming to it later on I can say it has not aged particularly well.Unlike the new AoE2:HD release, increasing the resolution unfortunately does not allow you to see more. Usually this is typical of competitive RTS games in order to keep the playing field even. Unfortunately how much is shown to you on screen is limited at best, especially when groups of units grow beyond the screen size, a particular issue when moving across a map with multiple unit types of varying speeds. AoE3 sports a more to-ground camera perspective causing vision to be obscured by walls or buildings to a far greater degree than the other AoE games. Not helping this is how the buildings are absolutely massive (houses are huge!) while this might make it seem like your town is more impressive than it is, navigating your town in a pinch can be very fiddly.Combat is unbalanced and to be fair, pretty broken. units can be queued but are all produced on the same timer. For example you can make 1 musketeer, or 5 at once in the same time. This all but removes the need to spend any resources until you need them. Most games I find end very quickly both online and against a computer.Unlike AoE3, the only realistic way to win is through combat, immeditae and unrelenting combat, removing a large portion of what an AoE game means to me. Naval combat has however improved significantly over previous installments, sporting a wide range of galleons and some very pleasing combat animations and damage manifesting visually through holes, masts falling and other immersive effects in constrast to AoE2's all-purpose flames.Overall I cannot recommend this game however I can see how it could appeal to those looking for a more basic RTS than is typically offered by the AoE franchise.

number of helpful: 3 of 17 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												I am a huge fan of the Age of Empires series in general, but for the most part AoE III just did not sit well with me. The graphics were good, but unfortunately that's about where to the good ended for me. I enjoyed the first few missions, but after that I began to dislike how the game was structured. For one, the maps were much too small compared to many AoE II campaign maps, but maybe it only seems that way because the HUD takes up a HUGE portion of the screen and is zoomed in more than other games making you blind to things 100 yards away. I can see myself playing through because it is nostalgic. The AoE franchise is one of the things I can attribute my love of gaming to and it has points for me from that. AoE III unfortunately is at the bottom of the list in terms of which I would recommend to a virgin of the series. If you can, pick up AoE (the first one, and don't skip Rise of Rome!!) or even better pick up AoE II on Steam.

number of helpful: 46 of 112 people (41%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												As someone looking primarily for a single-player RTS, I have to say I was disappointed. There are some interesting ideas and designs to this game, but as a single player experience I don't think either the campaign or the skirmish mode measure up, and I'd say in many ways inferior to games that came out 2-3 years earlier (Age of Myth, Rise of Nations, Warcraft III, etc.).What I liked:As a concept, the home city idea was very interesting. As a practical measure, I found myself using basically the same combo of cards every playthrough. It did make for occasional surprises (to be attacking an enemy city when they suddenly cashed in a bunch of units in your midst), but by and large, it became routine pretty quickly.   -Graphics are good, though some framerate issues even without settings maxedWhat I didn't like:-AI is terrible. In most of the campaign, you'd have to make a pretty major mistake to actually lose. I didn't really have any need to learn the unit counters until the last scenario in Act II (which can largely be won by exploiting a single counter).  By the same token, your own units will wander off and get themselves killed more often than you'd like.-Unit control isn't great. And sad that a 2005 release doesn't let you put units in multiple groupings. Want a group for all artillery for and a subgroup for just cannons for combat precision?  Too bad!-Reward for advancing ages was implemented better in the earlier 'Age of Mythology.' There the rewards represented actual tactical choices with pros/cons. Here the proper choice is often a given. "Let's see - do I want a boat reward on this map with no water or whatever option B is?"Maybe this game is great for multi-player, I can't say. But as single-player goes, it was disappointing.  Honestly I can't say it would even make my RTS top 10, despite the few things it does do well.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												They should call this Age of Empires Not. I've always liked Microsoft Games Division because they made quality games. I've been an AoE player as long as I can remember, but this is not AoE. Here's why.Someone in a meeting during the development of this game, who has obviously never played the game,  must have raised their hand and said these 10 Things;1. Hey, you know that scenario creator thing? No one really uses that, and the ones that do really don't like it being so easy to use. So let's make one that's much harder to use. 2. Let's don't let them save game when testing a scenario so it can be played as a game later. No one does that. 3. And those random maps? Ah, you know they don't use that so let's take that out too. 4. When selecting an AI, instead of just selecting one for the computer, let's make them also place objects in the game to make it actually work.5. And here's something really fun to them. When they create a scenario and choose human for player 1, computer for all the other empires, and select AI's for the computer players, here comes the fun part; When they go to play the scenario, we'll switch them from player 1 to another player instead. They'll find that really funny!6. And you know those formations that you could use in older versions of AoE? I don't think anyone uses that. Let's remove that.7. Patrols? Why would they want their troops to patrol? Nah. Take that out too.8. And you know those towers? People build way too many of them. No one needs more than 7, so let's put a limit on them. Even if one player gathers more resources, they shouldn't be allowed to build unlimited towers. No one should ever build more than 7 in my opinion and people should play it the way I would play it, not just any way they want to.9. Same with Ships. They shouldn't build so many, so let's limit that too.10. Oh and this one is real important. Players used to have the ability to place waypoints from their barracks, stables, etc. at an enemy location and fill the queue with 15 troops from each one and if it was more than the population limit, they wouldn't be made until the pop fell below the limit. Instead, in the new AoE, let's not let them schedule those troops in advance. If they want reinforcements, make them go back and do that during the attack so the other player gets a break.Those aren't all of the problems with the new AoE compared to the excellent older AoE versions, so other people who never played the game must have also raised their hands too.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												Being a long time fan of Age of Empires: 2, I bought this game a long time ago, way before it came to steam. At that time I thought it was mediocre, the mechanics being odd, why do some things require buildings and some do not? There are no great ways to get resources, everything costs more and takes longer to build so you are looking at lower villager counts but higher resource costs, it is ridiculous. Much harder to build a good economy and military. Also there is the fact that you can build gunpowder units at the same time as archaic units. Why would you use crossbowmen when you could have musketeers? The two didn't exist at the same points and so it makes the game "feel" weird. Not to mention everything is in a frontier/colonial era. Why are there pikemen at all? Makes no sense. All in all this is a horrible sequel to the amazing second installment and I will be spending my time on the second one.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												I was expecting the same level of fun that the first two Age of Empires gave, but I didn't exactly recieve that. Let me just say that the game feels...small...in comparison to other games like it and to its own games. There are only a few unit types, the research and upgrades feel dull, the maps are a little weird, and the UI looks really bad for 2009. (Sure the UI shouldn't give the game a lower score but it is the one continous thing on your screen the whole time playing which can help you find buttons and/or match the game so it doesn't look out of place) Also there really is no strategy, as you just need a more researched army and big a economy. On top of this the Campaign is uninteresting and the weird home city hub never truly fascinated me. Nothing feels dynamic it all feels linear.And lastly the AI feels like it has an upper hand when I was playing on Normal, as their cities weren't as built up as mine for most of the game. Now here are the good parts about the game. Graphics are solid, Building Destruction is nice, Units speak in their native language, building management, and resource gathering is perfect.My FINAL SCORE is, (5/10) I love rts games but this feels weak compared to past installments and other rts games. If this game was 20$ I would be happier but this costs 40$!! And this game feels way too short with little variety to keep the ages feeling bigger and last longer. Thank you for your time.

number of helpful: 6 of 24 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Don't buy this game for it's name. Actually, it's a shame for the outstanding AoE franchise.AoE III is a wonderful game, with good graphics and enough in-game possibilities (i'm talking about buildings and characters), but it lacks the supremacy of AoE II and AoE.This game looks like the developers wanted to make a game that would ressemble the very first Empire Earth. Well, it doesn't. - Remember that awesome feeling in AoE II and EE when changing the map size to 'gigantic' and you had no idea where to start exploring first? You won't find it here. According to me, this game stands or falls with the scale of its maps.- Also a big fail is the building-aspect. You don't have the feeling, when building your houses and military buildings, that you're constructing a city. After putting your, let's say 20, buildings close to each other and in an structurised manner, it looks like a mismatched slum of the 14th century which you want to put on fire. I know, some of you will say: 'Oy, AoE isn't about building, it's the fighting that counts!' And i'll even say they're correct. But be honest with yourselves, it's the whole that counts, isn't it?- Another, rather 'stupid', improvement is the fact that in-game you have the possibility to make your homecountry deliver supplies (troops, food and villagers). Seriously, who gives a damn for this? This makes you feel incompetent for playing this game, since you'll have to 'beg' for help. Not a nice feeling, not?The lot of you will buy Age of Empires III for the name and because you expect it to be even better than AoE II and EE. But don't be fooled by the name, nor the metacritic score; this game isn't worth buying for the full price.In sale? Well, yeah, with a 75% Steam sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 13 people (8%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												as a veteran of the RTS genre there are a few words I’d have for this gamelets start with what is good. for a game made in 2005 it has very good graphics. And the way buildings fall apart when damaged is very satisfying. There are ALOT of choices for what units to build.That being said there are far more negatives in my opinionthe controls are clunky at best and hot keys are far from intuitive or fast. The 'cards' add a level of complexity that is completely unnecessary. The units and their counters are so hard that there is almost no point to getting more then the other guy and if you don't have the perfect mix to take him down there is almost no chance to heavily damage his army let alone kill it. Field artillery is far over powered. Workers are absurdly expensive but I suppose that was a balance decision to make up for the fact the resource gathering and macro, if you can call it that, is so simple that it makes where to send your workers to gather minerals in starcraft seam arduous. Factions are far from balanced and not in the good way that promotes a healthy meta game. The computer AI if you can call it that is a joke and needs some serious attention. Battles even when they are at peak seam sluggish or everything is dead before any exchange has happened and micro is almost a joke.In conclusion. Never buy this game when it's not on sale and your money would be far better spent buying age of empires two and it's expansion for cheaper

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												This game does have some good things although I have found that Age of Empires 2 has more to offer than Age of Empires 3.Reason I would choose AoE2 over AoE3..- More people to choose- More structures to build- Larger maps- More customizability- Easier to create things and understand things.- Better customizable economy (can choose to start with 500 of each resource and work your way up from scratch vs 20k to start)- Stone resource. (Some may argue this makes it harder and more of a BS resource but at the same time, its not a max out and win game.)- Stronger structures with more unit specializes.- More of a story- A lot more.Things AoE3 has against AoE2- Better graphics- Better UI- One off screen to choose things to summon in from, "Levels"- Level up (One hero that you normally need to ransom to get anywhere.)- If you group someone into group 1 and hold down the 1 button, it doesn't stop the unit dead in its tracks (Until the button is released.)If your going to buy this game, wait for it to go on sale otherwise your wasting your money..If your going to buy AoE2 and like stratedgy games that you can waste hours on end, then buy it any time. I could easily sink a day in just playing a couple games without realizing that I just went from 8am to 11pm, having missed work due to forgetting the time.

number of helpful: 19 of 53 people (36%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Do NOT buy this game.  The UI is half-@ssed; another grind-for-gear fest.= Graphics =+ Water looks beautiful !+ Ships are properly to scale -- they are BIG !+ Physics for destroying buildings and units look great -- especially heavy artillery !- Icons for buildings and units are extremely bland; ALMOST as bad as "Ultima Online."- Every 3D model in game is "fully lit" making it hard to recognize things you CAN click on and things you CAN'T click on.  The artists didn't understand Contrast ratio nor S/N ratio -- it is TOO HARD to find when crates or bags of gold get delivered to your colony due to foreground objects blending into background objects.  See this excellent talk to understand how to do background + foreground + UI properly:http://gdcvault.com/play/1015306/The-Art-of-Diablo= Gameplay =+ New card system is interesting- You have to *grind* to unlock cards for EACH city and civilization  You can no longer select your civilization in multiplayer; you must first build a home city.   LAME.- Teams are limited to 2 instead of 4 as in AoE2 so you can no longer have multiple, separate, computer teams.- You can only reset your deck ONCE !?!? More grind-for-gear crap.- Stone resource removed from the game. :-(- Computer AI cheats like crazy in Hard and Expert. (See next post for details)= UI =* The default camera zoom is too close to the ground.  Change "Camera Zoom" to "Very Far" in "Game Options" to fix.- Selecting a group no longer shows the individual health bars -- it is extremely hard to tell WHICH unit needs healing- The UI chews up 1/3 of your screen (WHY??) unless you go into Options and turn on "Enable Minimized UI."  - When you are unable to unlock a card the error message is too generic and doesn't tell you WHY.- No "TEAM" icon next to cards to EASILY tell which cards benefit the team.- Stupid default UI settings.  Why is "Show Gathers per Resource" OFF by default??- The status bar at the top in AoE2 that was easy to read of resources summary has been moved to the clunky bottom UI where it blends in making it WAY too hard to read.- Tooltips for buildings and units don't work if the item is in the queue.  *facepalm*- There is no option to remember your password; 2013 and still no auto-login??- Creating a multiplayer game with a password requires you press a retard "Password Protected" button IN ADDITION to typing in the password. Gee, how about using a -blank- password to determine if the game is password protected or not like every other online game??- Can only have 9 groups instead of 20 in AoE2- Can only have 50 units in a group instead of 75 as in AoE2- Can only have 200 max population with no way to increase it.  This _IS_ 2013 and we have quad-core computers these days ... why can AoE2HD be patched to up the limit but this game can't?- Hotkey for Flares was removed *sigh*- You MUST _first_ create an ES Online account with the ORIGINAL game, THEN you can "upgrade" it with the Expansion.  LAME.- The password box doesn't work in the original host game UNLESS you press the TAB key. LAME.= Support =MS Support are a bunch of R.E.T.A.R.D.S.  I misspelt my ES Online name and there is no way to either rename or delete your account !?!?  WTF is this ... 1977 ?Edit: Fixed spelling mistakes, added note about computer AI cheating.Edit.2 Valve censoring "re-tard" is lame.

number of helpful: 0 of 11 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2012
												Honestly? ♥♥♥♥ this game.I was a fan of Aoe 2, and I've had a lot of fun with it, so i picked this up to see if I could enjoy it too.The tutorial went well-ish, not very interesting, even by RTS standards. noteable that they get rid of the usual RTS tutorials in favor of just giving you a skirmish round with a narorator as you do♥♥♥♥♥♥After that, tried campaign. Not fun, gave up.Tried a skirmish mission on the very easiest difficulty, with the intent of learning the ropes. Built  a base. felt a little insubstantial. Built army. Charged into battle against one of my enemies. Killed their army with heavy casualties, okay. started attacking base, and was mulched by their incoming allies. My allies then say "You suck, we should just give up because we'll lose no matter what."New army, new attack, same result. Allies do nothing, insult me.So ♥♥♥♥ you Aoe3, wasn't a hard game to make a fun sequel to, you didn't have to change almost anything. Do. Not. Buy. At 10$ It wasn't worth it.
